timeline.bodyText:
minor:
consider introducing a builder for CaseEventFieldComplex rather than telescoping constructors:
https://www.vojtechruzicka.com/avoid-telescoping-constructor-pattern/
timeline.author: mario-paniccia

timeline.bodyText:
can we use
caseField.isCollectionFieldType()
caseField.isComplexFieldType()
?
timeline.author: mario-paniccia

timeline.bodyText:
To improve code readability it is essential to introduce utility methods to the domain classes whenever possible.
hasDisplayContextParameterType could be removed. We could introduce a method in DisplayContextParameter class that allows to check the type of a DCP. For example:
displayContextParameter.hasType(DisplayContextParameterType.DATETIMEENTRY)
Then we could add a method to CommonField that returns the display context parameter as an instance of DisplayContextParameter other than a String.
If we do that this will simplify in:
field.getDisplayContextParameter.hasType(DisplayContextParameterType.DATETIMEENTRY)
This is much more reusable and readable
timeline.author: mario-paniccia

timeline.bodyText:
getDisplayContextParameterOfType(displayContextParameter, DisplayContextParameterType.DATETIMEENTRY)
I think the code would be simpler if CommonField had the diplay context parameter already converted into a list of DisplayContextParameter rather than a raw String. Same as it has a List<AccessControlList>.
If that was the case, then CommonField could have a method getDisplayContextParameterOfType(DisplayContextParameterType.DATETIMEENTRY)
timeline.author: mario-paniccia

timeline.bodyText:
If I'm not wrong here we are failing the case update operation if the date field is not in the format specified in the DisplayContextParameter. This won't be an issue with the UI because it's going to send us the date fields in the correct format.
But what about Services that are invoking the update event programmatically? They will still be passing unformatted date fields probably (in ISO8601 format)? will those calls throw exception?
In case the date is already in ISO8601 format, does the dateTimeFormatParser.convertDateTimeToIso8601 throws exception?
We should allow date fields that are already in ISO8601 format rather than throwing exception. Can you make sure we have an integration test for this please.
We need to speak with BAs to understand the behaviour in this situation and state it clearly in the ticket for future reference
timeline.author: mario-paniccia
mario-paniccia
mario-paniccia

timeline.bodyText: minor: building a field's path it's common logic that could be encapsulated in a common class or utility method. If we don't have something we can reuse already

timeline.bodyText:
I'm a bit puzzled by this choice. Wouldn't it be more consistent with the current design if we had enhanced the DateTimeValidator and DateValidator to do the validation of the formatted date. And if successful then do the conversion?
Instead we are converting to the internal unformatted date before doing the validation
timeline.author: mario-paniccia

timeline.bodyText: why DataProcessing exception should be a subclass of ValidationException? in theory we could have processing errors that have nothing to do with validation
timeline.author: mario-paniccia
